annotation.TEXT: As you can probably tell, the collision areas for solid ground is all over the place. There are numerous invisible holes littered through-out this stage, while on the flip side, there's also solid ground over what should be pits. That's also not to mention the background (which doesn't seem like it was made for looping, but that didn't stop qazcake from doing it anyways).

From what I've seen, Top Spin makes you relatively invincible to nearly anything (aside from spikes) while it's in use. The glitch that drains all of its ammo isn't present. With that being said however, you can still burn through it by hitting multiple enemies at the same time.

From what I understand, this stage is an inside-joke related to another level contest hosted by the talkhaus. Evidently, someone submitted a level that was nothing but a vertical drop for a few screens (much like what you're seeing here).

I'm actually not sure if it's possible to beat this stage without abusing Rush Jet. To be honest, I'd rather fight the Orphan of Kos with my bare fists than try to find out (and with that, my quota for a shameless reference to a potential future playthrough series has been met - just minus the bare fists part).

As far as this character goes...I have no idea. I'm not sure who she is or where she's from (unless she's an original character of some kind). You can't interact with her either, which basically makes her more scenery than NPC.

Granted, this stage does mix things up a bit by being a climbing level rather than a descending one (and as such, gives the opportunity to study the room and reset it before attempting it). You can also use the Black Hole Bomb to block out the lasers briefly, as seen here. Even with all that in mind however...this is still a stage that relies on instant-deaths as its main gimmick. Aside from Death Man's level in Rock Force, I can't name a single instance where this has ever been executed even remotely well.

Thunder Wool actually isn't half-bad this time around. The cloud no longer flakes out after hitting an enemy, and you can have multiple clouds on-screen at the same time. Meanwhile, we also have the Black Hole Bomb; Which retains its destructive power and large hitbox...but it's extremely finicky. Sometimes you can trigger it with a button press, sometimes you can't. This mostly seems to happen around shielded enemies for some reason (which is annoying, seeing as the black hole would be great for dealing with them otherwise).

Moving into the game proper at this point, let's go over the basic run-down: As hinted by the dialogue, the game is separated into different areas (the different festivals being each tier/placement of the levels). You can go through them in any order, though you'll have to complete all of them if you want access to the Wily stages.

And yes, there are invisible pits in this hallway as well. If you do want to try this the normal way, my only advice is to spam Rush Coil and see where he lands and where he doesn't. Even then, I can't imagine it would be anything other than an excruciatingly painful/boring process.

The warnings of this level having issues aren't to be taken lightly. I have no idea what went wrong here, but this entire level is broken to the point of being nearly unplayable. I still wanted to give at least one honest shot at beating it normally, even though it's definitely not worth doing so.

Just to note: Given the somewhat slow speed of the text, and given how long some of the judge's comments are, I'm mostly going to breeze through the info on the signs/envelopes. I'll still interact with them, though you'll want to pause the video to read the full comments if you wish. If it helps, I've also linked the thread with full transcripts of the judge's comments in the description (along with time-stamps for each of the levels).

On the far opposite end of the spectrum, we have this level (which is aptly named "Level"). Unlike with City Wars, this is basic in pretty much every regard. I can't help but echo Duvi0's comments slightly, in that this feels like something that was put together to test out the level maker more than anything.

A little while back, I remember seeing an announcement for this particular contest on the Sprites Inc. forums. I didn't enter (seeing as I was busy with real life issues at the time), though I was still interested to see how it would turn out. With the judging complete and the levels being put into a full game, I can't exactly resist checking it out and giving my own two cents on the content within.

So, the original version of this annotation essentially claimed that nearly all instances of Quick Man's lasers are bad and that they should have been banned from future contests. Some of you might be pleased (or more likely, shocked) to hear that I've since changed my views on this, seeing as...well, I was straight up wrong. Are the quick beams an inherently bad idea? Not necessarily. It's just that they tend to be implemented in really obnoxious ways (see: this stage, or Rainbow Man's stage from MMU).

Even though he has an extended move-set here, Jolt Man is actually a lot easier than he was in Eternal. The only slight annoyance with this fight is a certain projectile of his (which is fired off after he's done walking from one side of the room to the other, and doesn't really have a visual telegraph). Beyond that, he's relatively slow and easy enough to deal with.

Functionality-wise, Mega Man controls somewhat similarly to Square Root of Negative One (not too surprising, since both games are edited from Blyka's engine). As for weapons, the arsenal in this game was actually determined via poll. For the most part, the weapons mimic their original counterparts, but with a few notable exceptions.
